reviewText: This was a lost gem. It has to be unique. The performances by Walter Brennan and the boy are truly touching. You also get to see Sidney Poitier in an early, but pivotal, role. It catches the poverty that existed in the South long after the War Between the States (due to various laws that continued in effect till as late as 1960) that affected all in the region. It showed how dignity and truth do not just belong to those well off and how this youngster was able to make a decision that broke his heart. Beautiful film.

reviewText: "Good-bye, My Lady" was made in 1956 and stars Walter Brennan.Phil Harris, Brandon de Wilde and Sidney Poitier.Beautifully filmed on location in black and white, this is a verysensitive and moving film aimed straight at the heart.Skeeter (Brandon de Wilde) is a 14 years old orphan boy who liveswith his uncle Jesse Jackson (Walter Brennan) in the PascagulaSwamp in Mississippi. Their home is a single room shack and theirlives very simple in a harsh, lonely and mundane environment,until one day when Skeeter finds a strange dog which turns out tobe a rare African Basenji Hound, the best hunting dog in the world.Skeeter can't resist the dog. She is his pride and joy, hisresponsibility, his best friend and as he does not know who owns her,he abides by the rule of finders keepers.Eventualy, he finds out who owns the dog from an advertisement in amagazine and that there is a large reward on offer for its return.Skeeter is then torn between what his heart and his conscience tellhim to do. Finally, he decides to return the hound to its rightfulowner and in the process becomes a man.The story which is based on James Street's novel is a gentle dramaboth simple and charming.Recommended viewing.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a little known movie, but what a jewel. It is in my opinion the best of Walter Brennan. Usually he plays the comedy parts, but in this movie he plays a most tender role. This is an excellent movie for the family and it also teaches us some of what it is like for a boy to grow up and encounter some of the challenges in the process. I highly recommend this for family viewing. It is a winner all around!

reviewText: "Goodbye, My Lady" (1956) is a hard one not to love.  Director William A. Wellman directed the first Best Picture winner, "Wings" and many other films and has not always had successes, and Warner Archive even includes a teaser trailer when the title of this picture was changed probably to help sell it another way.  The actors are all capable but there is a little bit of uncertainty that they are giving the best performances of their careers.  Walter Brennan as the uncle and Sidney Poitier have been better, but young Brandon de Wilde connects as the young boy who finds the rare African breed dog Basenji in the bayou.  He names her "Lady" and most of the film is masterful with its evocative portrayal of backwoods bayou country and folk with a screenplay by Sid Fleischman based on the beloved novel by James Street ("The Biscuit Eater").  The film can not help but tug at your heartstrings, and is so involving that it transports you to a better time for 95 minutes, so don't waste it and watch it while there will be interruptions.  B&W.
Title: N/A
